abstract: A federal guarantee, which Bank of American does not want to repay, may have helped calm investors’ fears about the bank.
snippet: A federal guarantee, which Bank of American does not want to repay, may have helped calm investors’ fears about the bank.
lead_paragraph: Ken Lewis needs to get out his checkbook. Mr. Lewis, the Bank of America chief executive, never signed the deal he cut in January for the United States to backstop some $118 billion in Merrill Lynch assets. But that didn’t become known until May, when the bank announced it wouldn’t be taking the guarantee.

headline.main: An Unsigned Deal Could Be Costly

abstract: Bank of America, which is trying to avoid paying billions of dollars in fees for government guarantees against losses at Merrill Lynch, saying the rescue agreement was never signed, ought to pay up, Breakingviews says.
